definition: used before a noun to refer to a single thing or person but not a particular thing or person or not one that you have referred to before

definition: used to mean any or every thing or person of the type you are referring to

definition: one

definition: used to state what type of thing or person something or someone is

definition: used to show the cause of something, especially a feeling
examples: ['We were surprised at the news.', 'I was quite excited at the prospect.', 'Why does no one ever laugh at my jokes?']

definition: as much as, or more than, a number, amount, distance, etc
examples: ['It will cost at least £500.', "You'll have to wait at least an hour."]

definition: used after an adjective to show a person's ability to do something
examples: ["I'm not very good at skiing.", "He's very talented at maths."]

definition: used for emphasis in questions or negative statements, to mean in any way or of any type
examples: ['Can I help at all?', "He hasn't changed at all."]

definition: at the highest level of achievement or quality
examples: ['The article is an example of journalism at its best.']

definition: finally
examples: ["At last, I've found a pair of jeans that actually fit."]

definition: even if nothing else happens or is true
examples: ["If you can't manage to clean the whole house, at least make sure the kitchen is clean."]

definition: something that you say when you are telling someone about an advantage in a bad situation
examples: ["It's a small house but at least there's a garden."]

definition: at the beginning of a situation or period of time
examples: ["At first I thought she was unfriendly, but actually she's just shy."]

definition: If two things happen at the same time, they happen together
examples: ['We arrived at the same time.']

definition: immediately
examples: ["I knew at once that I'd like it here."]

definition: now
examples: ["At present she's working abroad."]

definition: used to reduce the effect of a statement
examples: ["I've met the President - at least, he shook my hand once."]

definition: used to show a price, temperature, rate, speed, etc
examples: ['He was driving at 120 mph when the police spotted him.']

definition: If something must be done at all costs, it is very important that it is done
examples: ['We have to succeed at all costs.']

definition: available for you to use at any time
examples: ['We will have a car at our disposal for the whole trip.']

definition: responsible for something bad that has happened
examples: ['I was at fault and I would like to apologize.']

definition: being in a situation where something bad is likely to happen
examples: ['All houses within 100 metres of the seas are at risk of flooding.', 'Releasing these prisoners puts the public at risk.']

definition: not horizontal or vertical, but sloping
examples: ['He wore his hat at an angle.', 'The boat settled into the mud at a 35 degree angle.']

definition: If you do one thing at the expense of another, doing the first thing harms the second thing
examples: ['He spent a lot of time at work, at the expense of his marriage.']

definition: If you accept something at face value because of the way it first looks or seems, you do so without thinking carefully about it
examples: ["You can't just accept everything you read in the newspapers at face value.", 'These results should not be taken at face value - careful analysis is required to assess their full implications.']

definition: If you see something at a glance, you see it very quickly or immediately
examples: ['He could tell at a glance that something was wrong.']

definition: near in time or space
examples: ['Teachers are always close at hand to give help to any child who needs it.']

definition: not less than, and probably much more than
examples: ['At the very least, you should apologize.', 'We should earn £500 at the very least.']

definition: only a short time before something happens
examples: ['I had to give a speech at very short notice.']

definition: at the same time
examples: ['They all started talking at once.']

definition: suddenly
examples: ['All at once he stood up and walked out of the room.']

definition: chosen by chance
examples: ['Winners will be chosen at random.']

definition: sometimes
examples: ["At times, I wish I didn't have to go to school."]

definition: used to show that the most positive way of considering something is still not good
examples: ['At best, only 50 per cent of babies born at 24 weeks will survive.']

definition: used to show that something is not good when it is the best it can be
examples: ["He's not exactly patient at the best of times."]

definition: having problems that other people do not have
examples: ['Being shy puts him at a disadvantage.']

definition: to not agree with someone or something
examples: ['His remark was at odds with our report.']

definition: If you tell someone to do something by a particular time at the latest, you mean they must do it before that time
examples: ["She said to be there by 8 o'clock at the latest."]

definition: If you talk about something at length, you talk for a long time
examples: ['We discussed both topics at length.']

word: be at liberty to do sth
definition: to be allowed to do something
examples: ["I'm not at liberty to discuss the matter at present."]

definition: not knowing what to do
examples: ["I'm at a loss to explain his disappearance."]

definition: not knowing what to say
examples: ['The question was unexpected and she was temporarily at a loss for words.']

word: be at the mercy of sb/sth
definition: to not be able to protect yourself from something or someone that you cannot control
examples: ['Farmers are often at the mercy of the weather.']

definition: used after a time or date to show that something will not happen before then
examples: ['Building will not begin until July at the earliest.']

definition: in order to make someone look stupid
examples: ['Stop making jokes at my expense.']

definition: If you have something at your fingertips, you can get it and use it very easily
examples: ['He had all the information needed at his fingertips.']

definition: If you suffer at the hands of someone, they hurt you or treat you badly
examples: ['She suffered terribly at the hands of her classmates.']

definition: used to say what someone is really like
examples: ["I'm just a kid at heart."]

definition: most important in what is being discussed
examples: ['The point at issue is what is best for the child.']

definition: If something useful is at a premium, there is not enough of it
examples: ['Time is at a premium just before the start of exams.']

definition: If you want something at any price, you will do anything to get it
examples: ['She wanted the job at any price.']

definition: used before saying what will happen if a situation continues in the same way
examples: ["At this rate we're not going to be there till midnight."]

definition: used before saying one fact that is certain in a situation that you are generally not certain about
examples: ['Well, at any rate we need her to be there.']

definition: If you do something at your own risk, you are completely responsible for anything bad that might happen because of it
examples: ['Customers may leave vehicles here at their own risk.']

definition: If something is at stake, it is in a situation where it might be lost or damaged
examples: ["We have to act quickly - people's lives are at stake."]

label: C usually no plural or U
definition: the force or action of one object hitting another
examples: ['The impact of the crash reduced the car to a third of its original length.', 'The bullet explodes on impact.']

definition: to affect something or someone
examples: ['Rising interest rates are sure to impact on the housing market.']

label: U
definition: when someone is impatient
examples: ['His impatience was obvious.']

label: never before noun
definition: easily annoyed by someone's mistakes or because you have to wait
examples: ["He's a good teacher, but inclined to be a bit impatient with slow learners.", "You'd be hopeless looking after children - you're far too impatient!"]

label: never before noun
definition: wanting something to happen as soon as possible
examples: ["He's got a lot of exciting ideas and he's impatient to get started.", 'People are increasingly impatient for change in this country.']

definition: in an impatient way
examples: ['"Yes, you said that before," she said, impatiently.', 'We were waiting impatiently for the show to begin.']

label: no plural
definition: the form of a verb which is usually used for giving orders
examples: ["In the phrase 'Leave him alone!', the verb 'leave' is an imperative/is in the imperative."]

definition: When an action or process is imperative, it is extremely important that it happens or is done
examples: ['It is imperative (that) I speak with him at once.']

definition: not perfect and with some mistakes
examples: ['an imperfect solution']

definition: not being friendly towards people or showing any interest in them
examples: ['a cold and impersonal letter']

label: T
definition: to make a law, system, plan, etc. start to happen or operate
examples: ['The changes to the national health system will be implemented next year.']

label: U
definition: when a plan or system is put into operation
examples: ['The implementation of the new computer system went smoothly.']

label: C
definition: a result or effect that seems likely in the future
examples: ['financial/health implications', 'This scheme has serious implications for the local economy.']

label: C or U
definition: when you seem to suggest something without saying it directly
examples: ['The implication was that the school had to do much better or it would be closed.']

label: U
definition: when someone is involved in something bad
examples: ['His career was ruined by his implication in the scandal.']

definition: suggested but not stated directly
examples: ['an implicit threat', 'We interpreted his silence as implicit agreement.']

label: T
definition: to suggest or show something, without saying it directly
examples: ["Are you implying (that) I'm fat?", "I'm not implying anything about your cooking, but could we eat out tonight?", 'I detected an implied criticism of the way he was treated.']

label: T
definition: If one thing implies another, the first thing shows that the second is likely to exist or be true
examples: ['Socialism implies equality.']

label: T
definition: used to show that the name of something tells you something about it
examples: ['The Long Room, as its name implies, runs the entire length of the house.']

definition: not polite
examples: ['It is impolite to point at people.']

label: T
definition: to buy or bring in products from another country
examples: ['We import a large number of cars from Japan.']

label: C
definition: a product which is imported from another country
examples: ['Japanese/American imports', 'cheap imports from Asia']

label: U
definition: when you import something into a country
examples: ['a ban on the import of beef']

label: U
definition: how important someone or something is
examples: ['Your views are of great importance to us.', 'The report stresses the importance of fresh food in a diet.', 'He emphasized the importance of following safety procedures.', 'The company recognizes the importance of regular staff training.']

definition: valuable, useful or necessary
examples: ['I think his career is more important to him than I am.', 'What are the most important ideas in this text?', "It's important for children to learn to get on with each other.", 'The important thing is to keep the heat low or the sugar will burn.']

definition: having a lot of power, influence or effect
examples: ['He was one of the most important writers of that period.', 'an important person/decision']

definition: in a way that is important
examples: ['If we served more soft drinks, there would be fewer hangovers and, more importantly, fewer drink-driving incidents.']

label: T
definition: to officially force a rule, tax, punishment, etc. to be obeyed or received
examples: ['Very high taxes have recently been imposed on cigarettes.', 'Judges are imposing increasingly heavy fines for minor driving offences.', 'The council has imposed a ban on alcohol in the city parks.']

label: T
definition: to force someone to accept something, especially a belief or way of living
examples: ["I don't want them to impose their religious beliefs on my children.", 'We must impose some kind of order on the way this office is run.']

label: C or U
definition: when something is impossible
examples: ["What you're asking just can't be done - it's an impossibility."]

definition: If an action or event is impossible, it cannot happen or be done
examples: ['It was impossible to sleep because of the noise.', 'It seems impossible that I could have walked by without noticing her.', 'He made it impossible for me to say no.']

definition: very difficult to deal with
examples: ["You just can't reason with her, she's absolutely impossible.", 'We found ourselves in an impossible situation.']

label: T
definition: to cause someone to admire or respect you
examples: ['He tried to impress me with his extensive knowledge of wine.']

definition: feeling admiration or respect for someone or something
examples: ['I was impressed by her professionalism.', 'He seemed suitably impressed by our efforts.']

label: C
definition: an idea, feeling or opinion about something or someone
examples: ["I didn't get much of an impression of the place because it was dark when we drove through it.", "What was your impression of Charlotte's husband?", "I don't tend to trust first impressions.", 'When I first met him I got/had the impression that he was a shy sort of a guy.']

label: no plural
definition: the way that something seems, looks or feels to a particular person
examples: ["It makes/gives/creates a very bad impression if you're late for an interview.", "He likes to give the impression (that) he's terribly popular and has loads of friends."]

label: C
definition: to think or understand a particular stated thing
examples: ["I was under the impression (that) you didn't get on too well.", 'He was under the mistaken impression (that) you were married.']

definition: Someone or something that is impressive makes you admire and respect them
examples: ["She's a very impressive public speaker.", 'That was an impressive performance from such a young tennis player.', 'an impressive collection of modern paintings', 'There are some very impressive buildings in the town.']

label: T
definition: to put someone in prison or keep them as a prisoner
examples: ['Taylor was imprisoned in 2005 for burglary.']

label: U
definition: when someone is kept in a prison
examples: ["She was sentenced to five years' imprisonment."]

label: I or T
definition: to get better or to make something better
examples: ['I thought the best way to improve my French was to live in France.', 'Her health has improved dramatically since she started on this new diet.']

definition: better than before
examples: ['improved performance/results', 'a new and improved recipe']

label: C or U
definition: when something gets better or when you make it better
examples: ["There's been a big/great/huge/major/noticeable improvement in her work this term.", "Sadly, Olivia's health has shown no improvement."]

label: C
definition: a change to something that makes it better
examples: ['home improvements']

label: C or U
definition: If there is room for improvement, something can be made better
examples: ["His work isn't bad but there's still some room for improvement."]

label: C
definition: a sudden feeling that you must do something, without thinking about the results
examples: ['Her first impulse was to run away.']

label: C
definition: suddenly and without thinking first
examples: ['I tend to act on impulse.']

definition: Impulsive people do things suddenly, without planning or thinking carefully, but because they want to
examples: ['In an impulsive gesture, he threw his arms around her.']

definition: inside or towards the inside of a container, place or area
examples: ["There's milk in the fridge.", 'Is Mark still in bed?', 'They live in an old cottage.', 'How much is that coat in the window?', "What's that in your hand?", "They used to live in Paris, but now they're somewhere in Italy.", "My daughter's in hospital overnight."]

definition: during part or all of a period of time
examples: ["We're going to Italy in April.", 'I started working here in 2007.', 'Life in the 19th century was very different from what it is now.', 'She was a brilliant gymnast in her youth.', "I haven't had a decent night's sleep in years/ages."]

definition: needing or using no more time than a particular amount of time
examples: ['Can you finish the job in two weeks?', 'Dinner will be ready in ten minutes.', 'She could get that essay done in a couple of hours if she really tried.']

definition: forming a part of something
examples: ['He used to be the lead singer in a rock band.', 'There are too many spelling mistakes in this essay.', "I've been waiting in this queue for ages."]

definition: close to the front part of something or where someone can see or hear you
examples: ['He parked the car in front of the house.']

definition: wearing
examples: ['Do you recognize that man in the grey suit?', "She's always dressed in red."]

definition: early or at the right time
examples: ['We arrived in time to catch the train.']

definition: before a particular time, or before doing a particular thing
examples: ["If you're going to come, please let me know in advance."]

definition: used to emphasize what is really true, or to give more information
examples: ['We met Rebecca for lunch. In fact, we spent the whole afternoon with her.', 'I was told there were some tickets left but in fact they were sold out.']

definition: further forward than someone or something else
examples: ['The car in front suddenly stopped and I went into the back of it.', 'She started talking to the man in front of her.']

definition: liking someone very much and having romantic or sexual feelings for them
examples: ['Have you ever been in love?']

definition: experiencing an emotion or condition
examples: ["She's in a bad/good mood this morning.", "You're in great danger.", "He's living in luxury in the south of France."]

definition: arranged or divided in a particular way
examples: ['We all sat down in a circle.', 'The desks were arranged in rows of ten.', 'Discounts are available to people travelling in large groups.', 'The books on these shelves are arranged in alphabetical order.']

definition: as well (as)
examples: ['In addition to his flat in London, he has a villa in Italy and a castle in Scotland.']

definition: finally, after something has been thought about or discussed a lot
examples: ['We were thinking about going to Switzerland, but in the end we went to Austria.']

definition: including or considering all the information about something or every part of something
examples: ["We haven't discussed the matter in detail yet.", 'The book described her sufferings in great detail.']

definition: completely and with nothing missing
examples: ['The bill must be paid in full by the end of the month.']

definition: beginning from now
examples: ['Could you be more careful in future?', "In future, I'm going to check every single piece of work that you do!"]

definition: usually, or in most situations
examples: ['In general, men are taller than women.', 'In general, the weather here stays sunny.']

definition: crying
examples: ['I found him in tears in his bedroom.']

word: in order (for sb/sth) to do sth
definition: with the purpose of achieving something
examples: ['He came home early in order to see the children before they went to bed.', 'She worked all summer in order to save enough money.']

definition: considering the whole of someone or something, and not just a particular part of them
examples: ['So, apart from the bad ankle, how are you in general?']

definition: to agree with or approve of a plan or idea
examples: ['Most people are in favour of reducing traffic in cities.']

definition: divided into two equal parts
examples: ['Cut the potatoes in two.', 'Divide the dough in half and roll it out into two circles.']

definition: used to emphasize what is really true, or to give more information
examples: ["I thought she was Portuguese, but in actual fact she's Brazilian."]

definition: expressed or written in a particular way
examples: ['They spoke in Russian the whole time.', 'Why not do a rough answer in pencil first?', 'Complete the form in (black) ink.']

definition: especially
examples: ['Are you looking for anything in particular?']

definition: involved or connected with a particular subject or activity
examples: ['a degree in philosophy', 'advances in medical science', 'I never knew you worked in publishing.']

definition: because of a possibility of something happening, being needed, etc
examples: ["I don't think I'll need any money but I'll bring some just in case.", 'Bring a map in case you get lost.']

definition: when something happens, or in preparation for when something happens
examples: ['We keep a bucket of water backstage, in case of fire.']

definition: used to give another reason for something you are saying, or that you have done
examples: ["I don't want to go and in any case, I haven't been invited."]

definition: because of the mentioned situation
examples: ["There's no coffee left? In that case I'll have tea."]

definition: used to show the total amount of something
examples: ['Some of the children came, so there were 15 of us in all.']

definition: used when referring to something that is done as a result of something else
examples: ["I'd like to do something for you in return/exchange for everything you've done for me.", 'The changes are in response to demand from our customers.', "He refused to say anything in reply to the journalists' questions."]

definition: using only a few words
examples: ['world news in brief']

definition: in someone's opinion
examples: ["In my parents' eyes, I'll always be a child."]

definition: used to introduce the last part of a speech or a piece of writing
examples: ['In conclusion, I would like to thank our guest speaker for her fascinating talk.', 'In conclusion, swimming is an enjoyable form of exercise and an excellent way to keep fit.']

definition: used to say what something is about
examples: ['I am writing in connection with the above job advertised in The Daily Press on Monday 12th February.', "A man has been arrested in connection with last month's murder."]

definition: at a suitable time in the future
examples: ['The results will be sent to you in due course.']

definition: towards someone
examples: ['She keeps looking in my direction.']

definition: used to explain what something means in a different way
examples: ["He said he's too busy - in other words he isn't interested."]

definition: An agreement that is in writing is official and is proof of that agreement
examples: ['Please confirm your reservation in writing.']

definition: if vegetables or fruit are in season, they are available and ready to eat
examples: ['Asparagus is in season at the moment.']

definition: without telling other people
examples: ['For years they met in secret.']

definition: feeling good/excited/unhappy, etc
examples: ['The whole class was in good spirits that day.']

definition: because of
examples: ['In view of recent events, we have decided to cancel the meeting.']

definition: in order to celebrate or show great respect for someone or something
examples: ['a banquet in honour of the president']

definition: If you do something in person, you go somewhere to do it yourself
examples: ['You have to collect the document in person.']

definition: instead of something
examples: ['Try adding fruit to your cereal in place of sugar.']

definition: at the start of a situation
examples: ['Why did you invite her in the first place?']

definition: If something is true in practice, this is the real situation
examples: ['In practice, the new laws have had little effect.']

definition: in a place where nobody else can hear you or see what you are doing
examples: ['The meeting was held in private.']

definition: happening or being done now
examples: ['Repair work is in progress on the south-bound lane of the motorway and will continue until June.']

definition: when compared with something
examples: ['Salaries are low in relation to the cost of living.']

definition: about or relating to something
examples: ["I'd like to ask you something in relation to what you said earlier."]

definition: in a particular way, or in many ways
examples: ['The school has changed in many respects.']

definition: as an answer to
examples: ["I'm writing in response to your letter of 14 February."]

definition: one after another without a break
examples: ["He's just won the tournament for the fifth year in a row."]

definition: available in a shop
examples: ['Do you have the book in stock at the moment?']

definition: used to talk about a period in the past
examples: ['In those days, boys used to wear short trousers.']

definition: one after another
examples: ['He spoke to the three boys in turn.']

definition: as a result of something that is part of a series of events
examples: ['This could result in the loss of certain species of fish and this in turn poses a serious threat to the fishing communities along the river banks.']

definition: in the way described by a rule, law, or wish
examples: ['Both companies have insisted that they were acting in accordance with the law.']

definition: in order to collect money for a group of people who need it
examples: ['a concert in aid of famine relief']

definition: working together with
examples: ['The event was organized in association with the Sports Council.']

definition: in large amounts
examples: ['to buy in bulk']

definition: in the same way as someone or something
examples: ['In common with many working mothers, she feels guilty about leaving her children.']

definition: wanted or needed in large numbers
examples: ['Good teachers are always in demand.']

definition: if something happens
examples: ['An airbag could save your life in the event of an accident.']

definition: whatever happens
examples: ["I'm not sure if I'm coming on Friday, but in any event, I'll see you next week."]

definition: to be famous and often featured in the media
examples: ['Her new role means that she will be in the public eye.']

definition: If something is in your favour, it helps you to win or succeed
examples: ['Both sides have strong arguments in their favour.']

definition: the particular way in which something appears or exists
examples: ['The novel is written in the form of a series of letters.', 'The medicine comes in the form of a liquid or pills.']

definition: used to say what you really think
examples: ['In his heart he felt they were wrong.']

definition: because you want something good to happen
examples: ['She went to Paris in the hope of improving her French.', 'They wrote to the Prime Minister in the hope that he would help.']

definition: to help someone and give them an advantage
examples: ['It may not be in your interests to change jobs so soon.']

definition: If something is done or happens in the light of facts, it is done or happens because of those facts
examples: ['The drug has been withdrawn in the light of new research.']

definition: If you do something in moderation, you do not do it too much
examples: ['I only drink alcohol in moderation now.']

definition: to have difficulty making a decision
examples: ["I'm in two minds about accepting his offer."]

definition: something that you say when you are describing something using as few words as possible
examples: ['The answer, in a nutshell, is yes.']

definition: If someone or something is in position, they are in the place that they should be in
examples: ['The police were all in position.']

definition: approximately
examples: ['It probably cost somewhere in the region of £900.']

definition: relating to a particular thing
examples: ['I include payment in respect of your invoice of May 13th.']

definition: in the opposite order or way
examples: ['Do the same steps but this time in reverse.']

definition: very soon
examples: ["We'll be home in no time."]

definition: singing or playing the right notes
examples: ['Try to stay in tune.']

definition: as a result of something that is part of a series of events
examples: ['This could result in the loss of certain species of fish and this in turn poses a serious threat to the fishing communities along the river banks.']

definition: without any success
examples: ['I tried in vain to start a conversation.']

word: in no way/not in any way
definition: not at all
examples: ['This is in no way your fault.']

definition: thinking about something in a particular way
examples: ["In a sense, he's right."]

definition: in a few words
examples: ['In short, we need more staff.']

definition: going to happen soon
examples: ["You never know what's in store for you.", "There's a bit of a shock in store for him when he gets home tonight!"]

definition: used to show when doing one thing is the cause of another thing happening
examples: ['In refusing to work abroad, she missed an excellent job opportunity.', "The government banned tobacco advertising and, in doing so, contributed greatly to the nation's health."]

definition: not knowing about something because other people are not telling you
examples: ['They kept us in the dark about their plans.']

definition: expecting something to happen or in preparation for something happening
examples: ["She's even decorated the spare room in anticipation of your visit."]

definition: present at an event
examples: ['They have doctors in attendance at every match.']

definition: to feel great respect for and sometimes fear of someone
examples: ['As children we were rather in awe of our grandfather.']

word: in the blink of an eye
definition: extremely quickly
examples: ['In the blink of an eye, he was gone.']

definition: in a cruel way, without showing any emotion
examples: ['He shot three policemen in cold blood.']

definition: to be in the same unpleasant situation as other people
examples: ["She complains that she doesn't have enough money, but we're all in the same boat."]

definition: not in a difficult situation or having problems any more
examples: ['We have had money problems but we should be in the clear by next year.']

definition: If you tell something to someone in confidence, you do not want them to tell anyone else
examples: ["I'm sorry, she told me that in confidence."]

definition: working, used, or happening with something or someone else
examples: ['Our librarians use their knowledge in conjunction with the computer network.']

definition: If bad things are done in the name of something, they are done in order to help that thing succeed
examples: ['So much blood has been spilt in the name of religion.']

definition: in the area near a place
examples: ['A number of buildings in the vicinity of the fire were damaged.']

definition: used to say that someone or something does something to a large degree
examples: ['They celebrate birthdays in a big way.']

definition: used when you repeat what someone said
examples: ["In the manager's words, the game was 'a total disaster'."]

definition: almost certainly
examples: ['The facilities are wasted on people who in all likelihood will not use them.']

definition: to be similar to and suitable for something
examples: ['They were offered a pay increase in line with inflation.']

definition: If you do something in memory of a dead person, you do it to show your respect or love for them
examples: ['They built a statue in memory of those who died in the fire.']

definition: in your imagination or memory
examples: ["In my mind's eye, she remains a little girl of six although she's actually a grown woman."]

definition: If something is in miniature, it is a very small copy of something else
examples: ['a model of the ship in miniature']

word: be in the mood for sth/to do sth
definition: to want to do or have something
examples: ["I'm not really in the mood for shopping at the moment."]

definition: used to say what the real situation is
examples: ['This means, in effect, that the plan has been scrapped.']

definition: used to emphasize the most important idea or quality of something
examples: ['In essence, its purpose is to contain information.']

definition: while having to deal with a difficult situation or problem
examples: ['She refused to leave him, in the face of increasing pressure from friends and family.']

definition: If you refuse or get rid of someone or something in favour of someone or something else, you choose them instead
examples: ['They dropped him from the team in favour of a much younger player.']

definition: immediately, or very quickly
examples: ["I'll be back in a flash."]

definition: being worked on or dealt with now
examples: ['Despite the pressures we are determined to get on with the job in hand.']

definition: used when you are saying what you really think or feel about something
examples: ["In all honesty, I'd rather not go."]

definition: used to give your opinion about something, often when you are sure you are right
examples: ["In my humble opinion, that's the wrong decision."]

definition: Something that is in its infancy has only just begun to develop
examples: ['In the 1950s, space travel was in its infancy.']

definition: in order to achieve a particular situation or quality
examples: ['In the interest of safety, passengers are advised to wear their seat belts at all times.']

definition: alone, or separately from other people, places, or things
examples: ['These poems cannot be considered in isolation.']

definition: partly
examples: ['He is in part to blame for the accident.']

definition: when things are in perspective, you think about them in a sensible and realistic way, and understand how important or unimportant they really are
examples: ["You must keep things in perspective - the overall situation isn't really that bad.", 'When you see pictures of their suffering, it puts your own problems in perspective.']

definition: in the correct position
examples: ['The chairs are all in place.']

definition: If a rule, system, etc. is in place, it has started to exist
examples: ['There are now laws in place to prevent this from happening.']

definition: If you agree with something in principle, you agree with the idea or plan although you do not know the details or you do not know if it will be possible
examples: ['They have approved the changes in principle.']

definition: used to mean that something is very likely
examples: ['She will, in all probability, have left before we arrive.']

definition: If something is being done, and something else happens in the process, the second thing happens as a result of doing the first thing
examples: ['She stood up to say hello and spilled her drink in the process.', 'The tunnel was built, but many lives were lost in the process.']

word: be in the process of doing sth
definition: to have started doing something
examples: ["We're in the process of painting our apartment."]

definition: If something changes in proportion to another thing, it changes to the same degree as that thing
examples: ['Your tax payment increases in proportion to your salary.']

definition: the person or thing that is being discussed
examples: ['He claims that he was in the pub with his girlfriend on the night in question.']

definition: If your bank account is in the red, you have spent more money than there was in it
examples: ["I expect I'm in the red again."]

definition: thinking now about something in the past
examples: ['In retrospect, I should probably have told her.']

definition: in a bad situation where you do the same things all the time, or where it is impossible to make progress
examples: ['He seems to be stuck in a rut at the moment.']

definition: to be acceptable in a way that will not upset or anger people
examples: ['His speech was in good taste.']

definition: to be unacceptable in a way that will upset or anger people
examples: ['He told a joke about a plane crash which I thought was in rather poor taste.']

definition: in a direct and often angry way
examples: ['I told him to go away in no uncertain terms.']

definition: to understand what someone wants or needs or to understand a situation and act in a way that is suitable for it
examples: ['The government is not in tune with the voters.']

definition: because of or for this reason
examples: ['The course is good in that it provides a very practical training.']

definition: into an area or space from the outside of it
examples: ['Could you bring the clothes in for me?', 'Cut the pastry into a square and turn in the corners.']

definition: at the place where a person usually lives or works
examples: ["Mr Ellis isn't in this week.", 'Could you ask him to ring me when he gets in?']

definition: having arrived at the place where people can get on or off
examples: ["What time is Roz's flight due in?"]

definition: given or sent to someone official in order to be read
examples: ['When does your essay have to be in?', 'Remember to get your application in by the end of the week.']

definition: If someone is in for a surprise, treat, shock, etc., it will happen to them soon
examples: ["If he thinks looking after a baby is easy, he's in for a shock."]

word: the ins and outs of sth
definition: the details of a particular subject
examples: ['the ins and outs of the legal system']

label: no plural
definition: when you are unable to do something
examples: ["I'm depressed by the police's inability to reduce street crime."]

label: C or U
definition: something such as a statement or number that is not correct
examples: ['The report contained many inaccuracies.']

definition: not correct or exact
examples: ['inaccurate information/figures']

definition: not good enough or too low in quality
examples: ['Our equipment is totally inadequate for a job like this.']

definition: not enough
examples: ['inadequate funds']

definition: not suitable
examples: ['inappropriate behaviour', 'It would be inappropriate for me to comment, without knowing the facts.']

definition: in a way that is not suitable
examples: ['The meeting was inappropriately handled and an argument broke out.']

definition: not able to do something or to feel a particular emotion
examples: ["I think she's incapable of love.", "He's incapable of controlling his temper."]

label: C or U
definition: something that encourages you to act in a particular way
examples: ['People had little incentive to save.', 'The government should provide incentives for young people to stay in school.']

label: C
definition: a unit used for measuring length, which is approximately equal to 2.54 centimetres, sometimes shown by the symbol
examples: ['Twelve inches are equal to one foot.', 'He had a cut an inch long above his left eye.', 'The snow was six inches deep in some places.', 'a piece of wood 2″ by 2″']

label: C
definition: an event which is either unpleasant or unusual
examples: ['an unfortunate incident', 'A youth was seriously injured in a shooting incident on Saturday night.']

definition: used when you add related but less important information to what has just been said or when you suddenly introduce a new subject
examples: ["Incidentally, talking of Stephen, have you met Stephen's girlfriend?"]

label: C or U
definition: a feeling that you want to do something
examples: ['She showed little inclination to leave.']

label: never before noun
definition: to have an opinion, but not a strong opinion
examples: ["I'm inclined to agree with you."]

label: never before noun
definition: often behaving in a particular way
examples: ['Tom is inclined to be forgetful.']

label: never before noun
definition: wanting to do something
examples: ['No one seemed inclined to help.']

label: never before noun
definition: having natural artistic/technical, etc. ability
examples: ["She's very curious, but not academically inclined."]

label: T
definition: to contain something or someone as a part of something else, or to make someone or something part of something else
examples: ['The bill includes tax and service.', 'Tax and service are included in the bill.', 'Your responsibilities will include making appointments on my behalf.', 'The group includes many ex-soldiers.']

definition: used to show that a person or thing is part of a larger group, amount or process
examples: ['Eight people, including two children, were injured in the explosion.', "It's £24.99, including postage."]

label: C or U
definition: when you include someone or something, especially in a group, amount, or event
examples: ['Her self-portrait was chosen for inclusion in the exhibition.']

definition: An inclusive price or amount includes everything
examples: ['Prices are inclusive of flights and accommodation.']

label: C or U
definition: money that you earn by working, investing or producing goods

definition: in a way that relates to your ability to think and to understand things

label: U

label: T

label: T

definition: extreme or very strong

definition: extremely

definition: with strong, serious emotions

label: U

label: U or no plural

label: U

label: C
